'''Stephen Thomas Azar''' (born April 11, 1964) is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, guitarist, and philanthropist. Active since 1996, he has released a total of seven studio albums: one on the former [[River North Records]], one on [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]], and five independently. Azar has charted nine times on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]], most successfully with his late 2001-early 2002 hit "[[I Don't Have to Be Me ('til Monday)]]", which reached the number two position there. After leaving Mercury in 2005, Azar began recording independently; ''[[Slide On Over Here]]'', his second independently-released album, charted the top-40 country singles "Moo La Moo" and "[[Sunshine (Everybody Needs a Little)]]" in 2009.

In addition to these albums, Azar released a number of standalone songs including a song to promote the [[National FFA Organization]] and a jingle for [[McDonald's]] restaurants. His 2017 album ''Down at the Liquor Store'' featured a number of guest musicians who had previously played for [[B. B. King]] and [[Elvis Presley]], and was credited to Steve Azar and the King's Men. Azar has written most of his own songs, and his style draws from country, rock, and [[Delta blues]], with his singing voice gaining frequent comparisons to [[John Mellencamp]]. In addition to his albums, Azar has also hosted a number of charities and music festivals. In 2017, he was named Music and Cultural Ambassador of Mississippi by that state's then-governor [[Phil Bryant]].

==Biography==
Stephen Thomas Azar was born April 11, 1964, as one of five children born to couple Joe and Virgie Azar, descendants of [[Lebanese Americans|Lebanese]]/[[Syrian Americans|Syrian]] immigrants, in [[Greenville, Mississippi]].<ref name="whitburn"/><ref name="comes home">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/282735490/ | title=Delta musician comes home | date=September 9, 2002 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Rebecca Hood Adams | location=Clarksdale, Mississippi | pages=1, 2}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=2017-08-04 |title=Steve Azar Brings In B.B. King's Backing Band For New Delta-Inspired Album |url=https://musicrow.com/2017/08/steve-azar-brings-in-b-b-kings-backing-band-for-new-delta-inspired-album/ |access-date=2024-08-22 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref> He began writing songs as a child, primarily for use in [[Mass in the Catholic Church|Catholic Mass]] and other liturgies at his church.<ref name="gary"/> When Azar was 10 years old, he began receiving guitar lessons from [[Delta blues]] singer [[Sonny Boy Nelson]]. He was a regular customer at a liquor store that Azar's father owned.<ref name="cmt 1"/> Azar had his first recording session in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], at age 15 when his father took him there to cut [[demo (music)|demo]]s.<ref name="gary">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/182533101/ | title=A career in gear | work=[[The Clarion-Ledger]] | access-date=January 15, 2021 | author=Gary Pettus | location=Jackson, Mississippi | pages=D1, D2}}</ref> After high school, Azar attended [[Delta State University]], from which he graduated with a degree in business management.<ref name="herald">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/80292327/ | title=Azar keeps 'Doin' It Right' | work=[[Herald & Review]] | date=September 23, 2005 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Tamela Meredith Partridge | location=Decatur, Illinois | pages=D8}}</ref> Azar began touring locally at various clubs around Mississippi with a band that included his brother, Joe Azar Jr. When one of his band members committed suicide and another was incarcerated for murder, he switched to performing as a solo act.<ref name="cmt 1">{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1454080/steve-azar-never-far-from-the-delta/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122175352/http://www.cmt.com/news/1454080/steve-azar-never-far-from-the-delta/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=January 22, 2021 | title=Steve Azar Never Far From the Delta | publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] | date=May 20, 2002 | access-date=January 15, 2021}}</ref><ref name="voa 1">{{cite web | url=https://www.voanews.com/archive/country-newcomer-steve-azar-waitin-joe-2002-04-30 | title=Country Newcomer Steve Azar is ''Waitin' on Joe'' | publisher=[[Voice of America]] | date=April 30, 2002 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref> In addition, he and Joe owed money towards equipment they had bought.<ref name="stark"/> After the payments had been completed, Azar and his wife moved to Nashville in 1993 so he could pursue a recording contract.<ref name="gary"/><ref name="stark">{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vxAEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22steve+azar%22+%22i+don%27t+have+to+be+me%22&pg=PA43 | title=Nashville Scene | author=Phyllis Stark | magazine=Billboard | pages=43 | date=April 20, 2002}}</ref>

==Music career==
===1993-2000: Early career===
Songwriter [[Roger Murrah]] discovered Azar performing at a Nashville nightclub and helped him sign a songwriter publishing contract.<ref name="gary"/> Dissatisfied with the fast pace of the contract and the inability to put "emotion" in his material, he ended his contract to sign with the independent [[River North Records]] in 1996.<ref name="terms"/><ref name="gary"/> That same year, he released his debut album ''[[Heartbreak Town (album)|Heartbreak Town]]''.<ref name="allmusic"/> The album's first two singles "Someday" and "I Never Stopped Loving You" both charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] in 1996.<ref name="whitburn"/> "Nights Like This" was also issued as a single, but it did not chart.<ref name="nights">{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eg4EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22steve+azar%22+%22nights+like+this%22&pg=PA77 | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=77 | date=July 12, 1997}}</ref> "Someday" also received a [[music video]] which aired on the former TNN ([[The Nashville Network]]).<ref name="gary"/> River North's founder, [[Joe Thomas (producer)|Joe Thomas]], produced the album except for the final track, which Azar co-produced with songwriter [[A. J. Masters]]. These three (along with Murrah and [[Bob Regan]]) were among the contributing musicians, and Azar co-wrote every track except for a cover of [[Paul Davis (singer)|Paul Davis]]' "[[I Go Crazy (Paul Davis song)|I Go Crazy]]".<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Heartbreak Town |others=Steve Azar |year=1996 |publisher=River North Records |id=CGD 1172 |location=Nashville, Tennessee}}</ref> An un-credited review in ''Billboard'' was favorable toward the album, comparing Azar's voice to those of [[Bruce Springsteen]] and [[John Mellencamp]]. Reviewers also commended Azar's songwriting and musical image.<ref name="bb heartbreak">{{cite magazine|date=23 March 1996|title=Reviews: Country|magazine=Billboard|page=75|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQ8EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22Steve+azar%22+%22river+north%22&pg=PA75}}</ref> A less positive review came from Larry Stephens of [[Country Standard Time]], who also compared Azar to Mellencamp vocally but felt most of the songs sounded too similar to each other.<ref name="larry">{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2599|title=''Heartbreak Town'' review|last=Stephens|first=Larry|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=January 17, 2021}}</ref>

Azar would later go on to deride ''Heartbreak Town'', stating in 2003 that the album "didn't even sound like [him]".<ref name="lex">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/693935266/ | title=He's got blues, but he's not down | work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] | date=August 29, 2003 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Walter Tunis | location=Lexington, Kentucky | pages=11}}</ref> His wife shared a similar opinion, and according to Azar, she cried after hearing the album because she felt that it did not represent him as an artist.<ref name="terms"/> After River North Records filed for bankruptcy and closed in 1997, Azar continued to tour the [[Southern United States]] and write songs. Despite the label closing, Azar had to wait two years to buy out his contract for $15,000.<ref name="terms">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/185550598/ | title=Singer finding fame on his own terms | work=The Clarion-Ledger | date=September 9, 2002 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Billy Watkins | pages=1D, 3D}}</ref>

===2001-05: Mercury Records===
Former River North executive Michael Powers had begun working at [[Mercury Records]]' [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Nashville division]] and recommended Azar to label executives. The company initially turned him down. However, a songwriting session with Rafe Van Hoy led to songs that both Azar and Mercury executives felt represented his artistic style, leading to his signing in 2001.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/429505370/ | title=A second chance has Azar singing a joyful tune | work=[[Times Leader]] | date=October 21, 2001 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Van Rose | location=Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania | pages=1G, 6G}}</ref><ref name="voa 1"/> His first Mercury single was "[[I Don't Have to Be Me ('til Monday)]]", which peaked at number two on the Hot Country Songs chart. It also accounted for his only entry on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], where it peaked at number 35.<ref name="whitburn"/> The song was the lead single to Azar's 2002 album ''[[Waitin' on Joe]]''. Van Hoy produced the album, and Azar wrote or co-wrote every song. They, along with blues guitarist [[Sonny Landreth]], were also among the contributing musicians.<ref name="stark"/><ref name="cmt 1"/><ref name="voa 1"/> "[[Waitin' on Joe (song)|Waitin' on Joe]]" was the disc's second single and also charted on Hot Country Songs in 2002.<ref name="whitburn"/> Both songs were also made into music videos; the latter's was filmed in [[Clarksdale, Mississippi]], and featured an appearance by [[Morgan Freeman]].<ref name="lex"/> Country Standard Time reviewer Jeffrey B. Remz called the album's production "a bit bright and polished", but praised Azar's songwriting and singing, particularly on the title track.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2598 | title=''Waitin' on Joe'' review | publisher=Country Standard Time | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref>

[[File:Morgan Freeman Deauville 2018.jpg|150px|thumb|left|[[Morgan Freeman]] appeared in the music video for Azar's 2002 single "[[Waitin' on Joe (song)|Waitin' on Joe]]".|alt=A headshot of Morgan Freeman wearing sunglasses.]]

Azar toured extensively throughout 2002 and 2003 to promote ''Waitin' on Joe'', averaging 250 shows per year.<ref name="lex"/> This extensive schedule led to him developing a [[cyst]] on his vocal cords, which was surgically removed in 2004.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.voanews.com/archive/steve-azar-mixes-country-rock-mississippi-blues-indianola | title=Steve Azar Mixes Country, Rock, Mississippi Blues on 'Indianola' | publisher=Voice of America | date=November 1, 2009 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref><ref name="herald"/> Also that year, "I Don't Have to Be Me" received a Million-Air Award from [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] (BMI) which commemorated the song for being played one million times on radio. Azar shared this award with the song's co-writers, Jason Young and [[R. C. Bannon]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/20041015steve_azar_i_dont_have_to_be_me_receives_million_air_award | title='I Don't Have To Be Me' Receives Million-Air Award | work=Broadcast Music Incorporated | date=October 14, 2004 | access-date=January 20, 2021}}</ref> His final single for Mercury was "Doin' It Right", which was released in mid-2005 but fell short of top 40 on Hot Country Songs.<ref name="whitburn"/> Following this single's under-performance, Azar ended his contract with Mercury.<ref name="hays"/>

===2006-08: Move to independent labels===
In 2006, Azar founded his own label called Dang Records. His first release for the label was a Christmas song called "Catfish Christmas", which he and Van Hoy cowrote.<ref name="whitburn"/> Over the next two years he began working on his next studio album. For this project, he served as producer and [[audio engineer]]. He also was credited playing acoustic guitar, electric guitar, [[slide guitar]], and [[mandolin]].<ref name="hays">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/1073040/ | title=Music, latest album takes Steve Azar back to country roots | work=[[Hays Daily News]] | date=June 25, 2006 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | location=Hays, Kansas | pages=E6}}</ref> In February 2006, Azar announced that Dang Records had partnered with [[Midas Records Nashville]] for the distribution of the album.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=102 | title=Steve Azar joins Midas Records | publisher=Country Standard Time | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref> He charted the [[Radney Foster]] co-write "You Don't Know a Thing" while on Midas.<ref name="whitburn"/> The song also received a music video which featured an appearance by golfer [[John Daly (golfer)|John Daly]].<ref name="daly">{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1539353/steve-azar-films-music-video-with-john-daly/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929024530/http://www.cmt.com/news/1539353/steve-azar-films-music-video-with-john-daly/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=September 29, 2021 | title=Steve Azar Films Music Video With John Daly | publisher=CMT | date=August 24, 2006 | access-date=January 21, 2021}}</ref> Between 2006 and 2007, Azar toured with [[Bob Seger]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1548863/steve-azar-to-continue-touring-with-bob-seger/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028091157/http://www.cmt.com/news/1548863/steve-azar-to-continue-touring-with-bob-seger/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=October 28, 2020 | title=Steve Azar to Continue Touring With Bob Seger | work=CMT | date=December 26, 2006 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref>

Azar experienced delays in releasing his material while on Midas, citing both creative differences and the label's inexperience.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/185803705/ | title=Miss. native Azar finds his voice | work=The Clarion-Ledger | date=August 6, 2009 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | location=Jackson, Mississippi}}</ref> This led to him exiting Midas and co-founding a new label called Ride Records in April 2008. On Ride, he released ''[[Indianola (album)|Indianola]]'' that same year.<ref name="ride">{{cite web | url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/38833/steve-azar-and-harry-nelson-launch-ride-records | title=Steve Azar And Harry Nelson Launch Ride Records | publisher=All Access | date=April 14, 2008 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1603 | title=Steve Azar forms label, plans to release "Indianola" | publisher=Country Standard Time | date=April 13, 2008 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref> While his first Ride single "I Won't Let You Lead Me Down" failed to chart,<ref name="ride"/><ref name="whitburn"/> his next single "You're My Life" reached number 52 on Hot Country Songs in 2009.<ref name="whitburn"/> At the time of the album's release, Azar said that many of the songs from the project grew from songwriting sessions with Foster and [[James House (singer)|James House]], and that he wanted to form an independent label so that he could have control over aspects such as sales and promotion. He, House, and [[John Brannen (singer)|John Brannen]] promoted the album through performances at Nashville's [[Bluebird Café]] in late 2008.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/279006531/ | title=Mississippi runs strong in new Steve Azar album | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=August 24, 2008 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | location=Nashville, Tennessee | pages=21}}</ref> Ken Tucker of ''Billboard'' found influences of country, blues, and rock in the production and songwriting choices, variously comparing tracks to Seger, [[Jackson Browne]], and the [[Traveling Wilburys]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2hIEAAAAMBAJ&q=steve+azar+indianola&pg=PA37 | title=Reviews | author=Ken Tucker | magazine=Billboard | pages=37 | date=May 31, 2008}}</ref> Ben Scott of ''[[The Oklahoman]]'' called the album "a nice mix of bluesy, contemporary rock with country influences".<ref name="okla">{{cite web | url=https://oklahoman.com/article/3271415/cd-review-steve-azar-indianola | title=CD Review: Steve Azar 'Indianola' | work=The Oklahoman | date=July 18, 2008 | access-date=January 17, 2021 | author=Ben Scott}}</ref>

[[File:Bob Seger 2013.jpg|150px|thumb|right|In 2006 and 2007, Azar toured with [[Bob Seger]].|alt=Rock singer Bob Seger, strumming an acoustic guitar and singing into a microphone]]

===2009-present: Further independent albums===
One year later, Azar released another album on Ride Records entitled ''[[Slide On Over Here]]''. Once again, Azar wrote or co-wrote every song. He told [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] that Seger was one of the primary influences in his songwriting: "he’s pretty much the entire gamut of emotions and I felt like I was leaving some of them in the drawer. So, I pulled them out for this record."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1620458/steve-azar-takes-the-ride-of-a-lifetime-with-bob-seger/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210121043209/http://www.cmt.com/news/1620458/steve-azar-takes-the-ride-of-a-lifetime-with-bob-seger/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=January 21, 2021 | title=Steve Azar Takes the Ride of a Lifetime With Bob Seger | publisher=CMT | date=August 31, 2009 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Whitney Self}}</ref> Azar co-produced the album with Justin Niebank, while both House and [[Josh Kelley]] co-wrote songs and provided backing vocals.<ref name="slide liner">{{cite AV media notes |title=Slide On Over Here |others=Steve Azar |year=2009 |type=CD insert |publisher=Ride Records |id=094922 863287}}</ref> Two of the album's singles, "Moo La Moo" and "[[Sunshine (Everybody Needs a Little)]]", both made top 40 on Hot Country Songs.<ref name="whitburn"/> The third single, "Hard Road", did not chart.<ref name="hard road">{{cite web | url=https://theboot.com/steve-azar-hard-road-lyrics/ | title=Steve Azar, 'Hard Road' - Story Behind the Lyrics | publisher=The Boot | date=April 25, 2011 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Alanna Conaway}}</ref><ref name="whitburn"/> Giving the album four stars ''[[Country Weekly]]'' critic Chris Neal called it a "pitch-perfect progression" from ''Indianola''.<ref name="cw">{{cite journal |last=Neal |first=Chris |date=August 3, 2009 |title=Reviews |journal=[[Country Weekly]] |volume=16 |issue=25 |pages=51 }}</ref> Azar's next album was ''Delta Soul, Volume One'' in 2011. The album featured four original songs and five re-recordings of previously-released material. James House once again contributed backing vocals. Matt Bjorke of Roughstock reviewed the album favorably, commending Azar's vocal performance along with the inclusion of [[slide guitar]] and [[Hammond organ]] in the production.<ref name="bjorke">{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2011/11/17749-album-review-steve-azar-delta-soul-volume-one | title=Album Review: Steve Azar - Delta Soul, Volume One | publisher=Roughstock | date=November 16, 2011 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Matt Bjorke}}</ref> The album's re-recording of "Doin' It Right" later appeared on the soundtrack of the 2012 [[Kevin James]] film ''[[Here Comes the Boom]]''.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.newswire.com/steve-azar-lands-song-in-new-kevin/195823 | title=Steve Azar Lands Song In New Kevin James Movie, 'Here Comes the Boom' | publisher=Newswire.com | date=September 20, 2012 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref>

Azar recorded a number of promotional singles throughout the 2010s. The first of these was 2012's "American Farmer", which the [[National FFA Organization]] sold at conventions.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.farmprogress.com/management/mississippis-steve-azar-celebrates-american-farmers-aids-ffa | title=Mississippi's Steve Azar celebrates American farmers, aids FFA | publisher=Delta Farm Press | date=May 10, 2012 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref> In 2015, Azar collaborated with Sophie Young to record the song "The Sky Is Falling (Patti Jo's Prayer)", which dealt with the subject of [[human trafficking]]. A high school senior in [[Portland, Maine]], heard the song and assembled a music video through the assistance of police detective Sgt. Steve Webster, a friend of Azar's. The music video was released on [[YouTube]] and its proceeds were donated to Not Here Justice in Action Network (a non-profit dedicated to the cause).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pressherald.com/2015/01/09/waynflete-students-music-video-tackles-human-trafficking/ | title=Waynflete student's music video tackles human trafficking | publisher=Portland Press Herald | date=January 9, 2015 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=David Hench}}</ref> In 2017, he recorded a television commercial jingle for [[McDonald's]] to promote their all-day breakfast menu.<ref name="digital">{{cite web | url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/steve-azar-talks-new-studio-album-down-at-the-liquor-store/article/499842 | title=Steve Azar talks new studio album 'Down at the Liquor Store' | publisher=Digital Journal | date=August 12, 2017 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Markos Papadatos}}</ref>

[[File:Azar club ebony.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Azar (second from left) with the King's Men, 2017.|alt=A black-and-white photo of Steve Azar and The King's Men, standing in front of a sign reading "Club Ebony" and "Coca-Cola".]]

Also in 2017, he assembled a number of musicians who had backed [[B. B. King]] and [[Elvis Presley]] to create a [[Delta blues]] project known as Steve Azar and the King's Men. The aggregation released the album ''Down at the Liquor Store'' in August 2017, which was accompanied by a making-of documentary titled ''Something in the Water'' filmed by Azar's son Strack. It was recorded at Club Ebony, a part of B. B. King's museum in [[Indianola, Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.clarionledger.com/story/life/mslife/2017/08/04/steve-azar/539338001/ | title=Steve Azar: There's something in the water | work=The Clarion-Ledger | date=August 4, 2017 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref> Markos Papadatos of Digital Journal called the collection a "sultry album", also stating that "One can hear Azar's heart on this record".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/review-steve-azar-the-kings-men-soars-on-down-at-the-liquor-store/article/499722 | title=Review: Steve Azar and The Kings Men soars on 'Down at the Liquor Store' | publisher=Digital Journal | date=August 10, 2017 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Markos Papadatos}}</ref>

This project was followed in 2020 by ''My Mississippi Reunion'', a collaboration with blues drummer Cedric Burnside. Each song on the album references a city or aspect of the state of Mississippi. The album's lead single, "Coldwater", was released that August.<ref name="musicrow coldwater">{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2020/08/steve-azar-debuts-coldwater-collaboration-in-advance-of-new-album-my-mississippi-reunion/ | title=Steve Azar Debuts 'Coldwater' Collaboration In Advance Of New Album 'My Mississippi Reunion' | publisher=MusicRow | date=August 20, 2020 | access-date=March 15, 2021 | author=Lorie Hollabaugh}}</ref> After its release, the [[Mississippi Institute of Arts and Letters]] named the album as its 2021 winner in the category of Best Contemporary Music Composition.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.ms-arts-letters.org/winners.html | title=Winners | publisher=Mississippi Institute of Arts and Letters | access-date=April 25, 2021}}</ref>

==Musical styles and influences==
In a 1996 article from ''[[The Clarion-Ledger]]'', news writer Gary Pettus stated that Azar considered [[Hank Williams]], [[B. B. King]], [[Conway Twitty]], and [[Neil Diamond]] to be primary musical influences. Pettus also wrote that "[w]hile the tunes themselves don't mimic the [[blues]] riffs Azar absorbed growing up in the [[Mississippi Delta|Delta]], the intensity and passion of his playing does."<ref name="gary"/> Azar also noted that both blues and country were influential in forming his style. He told CMT in 2002 that "Country music to me has always been about real life and real things and real people and real life situations, a lot like the blues was. I’m not a blues man, I didn’t live their life. I grew up around it".<ref name="cmt 1"/> As Azar largely writes his own songs, he has stated that he can "only write what I know, and I know the Delta". In particular, he said that his uncle Joe Nosef, a former mayor of Clarksdale, Mississippi who died of cancer at age 35, was one of the main inspirations behind "Waitin' on Joe".<ref name="comes home"/> Azar's singing voice has been compared to that of [[John Mellencamp]],<ref name="larry"/><ref name="bb heartbreak"/> with Ben Scott of ''The Oklahoman'' calling him a "younger, less jaded" variant of the same.<ref name="okla"/> Matt Bjorke of Roughstock called Azar's voice "buttery-smooth" and "soulful", comparing him positively to [[John Hiatt]].<ref name="bjorke"/>

Azar's musical representation of Mississippi has led to honors by two different state governors: [[Ronnie Musgrove]] declared March 13 "Steve Azar Day" to reflect Azar's positive portrayals of the state in the music videos for "I Don't Have to Be Me" and "Waitin' on Joe",<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1470438/mississippi-declares-steve-azar-day/ | title=Mississippi Declares Steve Azar Day | work=CMT | date=March 7, 2003 | access-date=January 16, 2011}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> while [[Phil Bryant]] named him Music and Cultural Ambassador of Mississippi in 2017.<ref name="delta"/> The latter also requested that Azar write a song to honor the state's bicentennial in 2017. This song, "One Mississippi", appeared on ''My Mississippi Reunion''.<ref name="musicrow coldwater"/> In 2022, state governor [[Tate Reeves]] signed a bill making "One Mississippi" the official [[state song]] of Mississippi.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.ddtonline.com/gov-reeves-signs-azars-one-mississippi-official-new-state-song#sthash.psQgyLHe.dpbs | title=Gov. Reeves signs Azar's 'One Mississippi' as official new state song | publisher=Delta Democrat-Times | date=June 18, 2022 | accessdate=July 6, 2022 | author=Jon Alverson}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Azar has been married to the former Gwen Nabholz since 1989.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2007/feb/09/mississippi-man-azar-making-music-friends-20070209/ | title=Mississippi man Azar making music for friends and family | publisher=[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]] | date=February 9, 2007 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Jack Hill}}</ref> The two met at a show where he was performing in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]].<ref name="terms"/> The Azars have three children: sons Strack and Adrian, and daughter Cecelia. They have resided in Greenville, Mississippi, since 2011.<ref name="delta"/>

In 2006, the two started the St. Cecilia Foundation, which raises money for children's musical education.<ref name="delta"/> Azar competed on a special week of the game show ''[[Wheel of Fortune (American game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' in 2007 which featured country music singers playing the game to raise money for charity, and raised $22,600 for the St. Cecelia Foundation on his episode.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1548088/country-stars-to-spin-on-wheel-of-fortune/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200805194131/http://www.cmt.com/news/1548088/country-stars-to-spin-on-wheel-of-fortune/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=August 5, 2020 | title=Country Stars to Spin on Wheel of Fortune | publisher=CMT | date=December 14, 2006 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite episode |title=Wheel of Fortune Country Stars Week, Episode 1 |series=Wheel of Fortune |network=Syndication |date=February 12, 2007 |season=24}}</ref> He also serves as a musical mentor and artist in residence for Delta Music Institute, which is part of [[Delta State University]].<ref name="delta">{{cite web | url=https://deltabusinessjournal.com/steve-azar-delta-man/ | title=Steve Azar, The Delta Man | publisher=Delta Business Journal | date=October 6, 2017 | access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref> Azar also enjoys [[golfing]],<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/steve-azar-annual-caddyshack-golf-tournament/ | title=Steve Azar gears up for annual Caddyshack golf tournament | publisher=[[Taste of Country]] | date=March 17, 2011 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Alanna Conaway}}</ref> and has been ranked by ''[[Golf Digest]]'' on multiple occasions as one of the most popular musicians who also plays golf.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.djournal.com/monroe/living/mississippi-son-shines-light-on-the-state-through-music/article_aca3cd44-af28-5194-9892-0fe6f848fb53.html | title=Mississippi son shines light on the state through music | publisher=Monroe Journal | date=April 12, 2019 | access-date=March 15, 2021}}</ref>

Azar started the Mighty Mississippi Music Festival, an annual music festival held in his hometown of Greenville, Mississippi, in 2013. The 2015 installment featured performances from [[Old Crow Medicine Show]] and [[Chris Stapleton]] among others. This festival is intended to honor country and blues musicians, mainly those who are natives of Mississippi.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/538163999/ | title=Steve Azar fuels excitement for Mighty Mississippi Fest | work=The Delta Democrat Times | date=October 1, 2015 | access-date=January 16, 2021 | author=Chris Caldwell | location=Greenville, Mississippi | pages=7}}</ref> The festival was relocated to Clarksdale, Mississippi, in 2020.<ref name="musicrow coldwater"/>
